section.title: Articles
section.sectiontitle: Use the definite article the with previously mentioned nouns.
section.text2a: Would you like an apple or a banana? The banana is very ripe.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the definite article the when specifying which one we mean, or when it is clear what we are referring to.
section.text3: There are lots of books on the shelf.
section.text3a: Yes, but where is the book I lent you?
section.text4a: Can you turn off the light please?

section.title: Articles
section.sectiontitle: Use the definite article when there is only one of something, and with superlatives.
section.text2a: It's the highest mountain in the Himalayas.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the definitive article for groups of islands or mountains, and for countries with plural names or the words state, republic or kingdom in their names.
section.text3a: Have you ever been to the Canary Islands?
section.text4a: She moved from the Netherlands to the United States.

section.title: Articles
section.sectiontitle: Use the definite article with rivers, oceans and seas; and with national groups.
section.text1a: The River Nile flows into the Mediterranean Sea.
section.text2a: The Romans took many ideas from the ancient Greeks.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use the definite article with inventions and species of animal.
section.text4a: The giant panda is an endangered species

section.title: Articles
section.sectiontitle: Use the indefinite article a / an with singular countable nouns mentioned for the first time, or when it doesn't matter which one we are referring to.
section.text1a: I'd like an apple and a glass of water.
section.text2a: I'd like to have a cup of coffee in a friendly café.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the indefinite article with jobs.
section.text3a: Jim's a teacher and his wife is an engineer.
section.text4a: She wants to be a film director.

section.title: Articles
section.sectiontitle: Use no article (the zero article) with uncountable, plural and abstract nouns used in their general sense.
section.text1a: Accommodation is difficult to find and hotels are expensive.
section.text2a: I think travelling is good fun.
section.sectiontitle2: Use no article with most countries, streets, villages, towns, cities, lakes and mountains.
section.text3a: He lives in Estoril but he works in Lisbon.
section.text4a: Lake Windermere is in the north east of England.
